newsitem.title: UK: LIFFE cocoa bounces late but still ends softer.
newsitem.headline: LIFFE cocoa bounces late but still ends softer.

text.p: LIFFE cocoa futures ended down on Tuesday but off session lows made after arbitrage between London and New York markets emerged in the afternoon.
The spread with lead month May cocoa in New York stood at about 211.53 at London's close as May closed down 1 at 1,016 stg per tonne on LIFFE. July ended down 4 at 1,028.

Outright activity was sluggish, but switches were active to help boost volume to a total 6,978 contracts. Traders said trade houses did switches in December/May 1998, December/July and December/September.
Once arbitrage evaporated, prices rebounded but failed to erase all losses.
In the near-term, traders and analysts expected mostly range-trading with some downside risk.
One trader saw the CFTC's Commitment of Traders report released over the weekend as a bearish sign. The report showed speculators accumulating more long positions.
An analyst at Merrill Lynch also said the market looked vulnerable because of the lack of encouraging fundamental news.

"Arrivals data has pointed to an even higher Ivorian crop than many had anticpated," Merrill Lynch said in its biweekly outlook. "Arrivals in the next weeks will confirm whether the mid-crop is indeed large. With the main crop figures better than expected, many feel there is little reason for the mid-crop to come in small, especially since earlier concerns about dry weather and possible stress to the crop has faded."

Weather analysts in Abidjan said on Tuesday that rains continued to strengthen over Ivory Coast's cocoa belt in mid-March after February's drought, favouring development of the mid-crop (May-September).
GNI forecasts a 1.1-million tonne Ivory Coast crop.
Some analysts also said sterling's recent rise against the dollar contributed to cocoa's failure to rally sharply.
But technically, analysts and traders were impressed with cocoa's resilience against a chart gap between 989 and 982.

Merrill Lynch said in a report that seasonals were pointing to a period of higher prices and increased volatility but warned that "price hikes are usually followed by an equally forceful selloff. With the open interest over 100,000 lots and speculators long, we see the market as extremely vulnerable."
For cocoa to look very bullish again, a trader said May would first have to rally above 1,048 stg and July through 1,055.
